articles.headline: Sugar Industry Highlights Conflicts Over Trade Pacts and Land
articles.snippet: For Cambodia and other poor nations, trade agreements that foster exports can also encourage land grabs by wealthy, politically connected families.
articles.abstract: For Cambodia and other poor nations, trade agreements that foster exports can also encourage land grabs by wealthy, politically connected families.
articles.lead_paragraph: OMLIANG COMMUNE, Cambodia — Yim Lon nurses bitter memories of how three years ago the local authorities forced her and her family to dismantle their small home and move it to make way for a sugar plantation.

articles.headline: Markets Assess the Impact of a Federal Shutdown
articles.snippet: Stock markets around the world steadied early on Tuesday after broad declines on Monday. The dollar, however, fell in value against major currencies.
articles.abstract: Stock markets around the world steadied early on Tuesday after broad declines on Monday. The dollar, however, fell in value against major currencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:04 a.m. | As investors cautiously pulled back from the markets, economists were grappling with how much a government shutdown could dent confidence in an already fragile economy.

articles.headline: Doubts Raised on Value of Investment Consultants to Pensions
articles.snippet: Individual investors are increasingly demanding transparency in performance track records, but pension funds — the biggest slice of the investment world — have conspicuously turned a blind eye to demanding track records from their most influential...
articles.abstract: Individual investors are increasingly demanding transparency in performance track records, but pension funds — the biggest slice of the investment world — have conspicuously turned a blind eye to demanding track records from their most influential advisers, investment consultants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s a brainteaser: Would you invest $10,000 in a mutual fund without knowing its past performance? Probably not. Yet, if you were in charge of $13 trillion of pension money, would you accept the recommendation of an investment consultant without knowing its performance record? The answer is yes. It happens every day.

articles.headline: Iran Staggers as Sanctions Hit Economy
articles.snippet: A currency shortage, created by Western sanctions, appears worse than previously thought, increasing pressure on leaders seeking to negotiate a nuclear deal.
articles.abstract: A currency shortage, created by Western sanctions, appears worse than previously thought, increasing pressure on leaders seeking to negotiate a nuclear deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The owner of a bus manufacturing company here admits that he is a man who likes his routines, and so every day he continues to commute to his downtown office. There he orders cups of tea, barks orders to his factory foremen over the phone and signs a steady flow of papers his employees put on his desk.

articles.headline: Financial Watchdog With Bite to Depart His Agency
articles.snippet: The head of the commission’s enforcement unit, who has taken on the financial industry, is stepping down.
articles.abstract: The head of the commission’s enforcement unit, who has taken on the financial industry, is stepping down.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Meister is waging legal battles against some of the biggest names in finance.

articles.headline: Conservatives With a Cause: ‘We’re Right’
articles.snippet: As House Republicans hope to triumph in their push to repeal, or at least delay, the Affordable Care Act, the distance between the House and the White House has never seemed greater.
articles.abstract: As House Republicans hope to triumph in their push to repeal, or at least delay, the Affordable Care Act, the distance between the House and the White House has never seemed greater.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, was the first to take to the Senate floor to publicly pose a question gnawing at an increasing number of lawmakers and ordinary citizens alike as the deadline for a government shutdown neared: Has Congress gone completely crazy?

articles.headline: End of an Aimless Summer: 3 Youths Charged in a Killing
articles.snippet: After the Australian native Christopher Lane was gunned down while visiting Duncan, Okla., three young men said they had shot him because they were bored and looking for a thrill.
articles.abstract: After the Australian native Christopher Lane was gunned down while visiting Duncan, Okla., three young men said they had shot him because they were bored and looking for a thrill.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNCAN, Okla. — It began as an afternoon jog in the steamy prairie heat.

articles.headline: Opening Rush to Insurance Markets Runs Into Snags
articles.snippet: Federal and state officials said that while they knew there was pent-up demand for health coverage, the number of visits to their exchanges was greater than anticipated.
articles.abstract: Federal and state officials said that while they knew there was pent-up demand for health coverage, the number of visits to their exchanges was greater than anticipated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans visited new online health insurance exchanges as enrollment opened on Tuesday, suggesting a broad national appetite for the affordable coverage that President Obama has promised with his health care law. But many people quickly encountered technological problems that prevented them from getting rates, comparing health plans or signing up.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough, Robert Pear and Richard Pérez-Peña
